results.title: Discovering the world (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children Thinking”.
First of four studies of the development of thinking in children from five to ten. Shows how their drawing and painting expresses understanding of their environment and traces its development.

results.title: Discovering the music of Japan (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media and Bernard Wilets
results.brief_description: In a beautiful teahouse setting, three of the major Japanese instruments - the Koto, the Samisen and the Shakuhachi - are shown. Historical background on each instrument and the ways they fit into current Japanese life are explained. Includes traditional Japanese singing and dancing, and a performance by an ensemble of the three instruments. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Discovering the Murray-Darling Basin
results.creator_credit: Kenyon Castle Productions, Murray-Darling Basin Commission (Australia) and Kenyon Castle
results.brief_description: Mike Hayes presents this video which shows the immense variety of Australia’s most important agricultural region, stretching from Queensland to South Australia. Not only is the area important agriculturally, but it is also an area of great beauty, rich in wildlife, history and folk lore. Produced for the Murray-Darling Basin Commission the program stresses that almost everybody in Australia is dependent in some way on this vast area and that therefore we should be working to prevent further degradation and repair some of the damage which has already been done.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kenyon Castle Productions, Murray-Darling Basin Commission (Australia) and Kenyon Castle

results.title: Discovering the forest
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Thomas Smith
results.brief_description: Presents the story of the forest community; discussing its conditions, forms of life and inter-relationships. The mood of the forest is established through its own atmosphere, sounds and life - there is no narration. Designed to encourage children to observe, and then interpret their observations.

results.title: Discovering texture (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Film Associates, Paul Burnford and Jack Stoops
results.brief_description: Explains that every surface has texture and than an object may have several textures. Points out that we learn about textures by touching the surfaces of objects and looking at the way light reflects from these surfaces. Shows how paints, tools and materials are used to change the texture of surfaces.

results.title: Discovering reinforcers (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: John Socha and Macomb Community College Instructional Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Effective Behavioural Programming”.
Tape 1 : The use of reinforcers in the classroom is the key to motivating students. Reinforcers are events that follow a response and increase the probability that the response will occur again. Retarded people have fewer reinforcers. It is important for a teacher to discover appropriate reinforcers for the particular class NB. This tape is on 525 line NTSC.

results.title: Discovering psychology
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: A challenging series of programs on human psychology hosted by veteran psychology professor, Philip Zimbardo of Stanford University. New developments are measured against historical breakthroughs and theories are tested by the recent findings of leading researchers.
results.description: A challenging series of programs on human psychology hosted by veteran psychology professor, Philip Zimbardo of Stanford University. New developments are measured against historical breakthroughs and theories are tested by the recent findings of leading researchers.

results.title: Discovering perspective
results.creator_credit: Film Associates of California, Paul Burnford and Jerry Samuelson
results.brief_description: We live in a world of depth and distance, which is called perspective. In drawing or painting on a flat surface, there are several ways in which to create the appearance of perspective: by overlapping and the placement of objects and lines, use of color, making objects clear or indistinct, and varying the size of objects.
